p: Lipid (oil) is the predominant macro component, and generally increases as the peanut seed matures [ 5]. For mature peanuts, total oil was reported to average about 50% on a fresh weight basis [ 6]. Oilseeds, such as peanuts, store most of their lipids in small, intracellular organelles commonly called oil bodies [ 7, 8]. Triglycerides form the majority of these oil bodies, and the interior triglycerides are encapsulated by a phospholipid bilayer and embedded oleosin protein. The oil bodies provide a stable energy reserve that can be accessed upon germination [ 9].
